questions.question: What is the primary purpose of green coffee grading?
choices: To determine the roast profile
To evaluate unroasted coffee beans for size, shape, and defects
To assess the flavor of brewed coffee
To set the market price for coffee
questions.answer: To evaluate unroasted coffee beans for size, shape, and defects

questions.question: Which of the following is considered a primary defect in green coffee?
choices: Slight insect damage
Broken beans
Full black beans
Uneven size
questions.answer: Full black beans

questions.question: What is the purpose of using screens in green coffee grading?
choices: To remove insects from the coffee
To sort beans by size
To separate different coffee varieties
To dry the coffee beans
questions.answer: To sort beans by size

questions.question: What is the 'first crack' in coffee roasting?
choices: The sound of beans breaking during grinding
An audible popping sound signaling the beginning of flavor development
The initial splitting of the coffee cherry
The cracking of the roaster drum
questions.answer: An audible popping sound signaling the beginning of flavor development

questions.question: Which roast level typically highlights the bean's original characteristics?
choices: Dark roast
Medium roast
Light roast
French roast
questions.answer: Light roast

questions.question: What is cupping in the context of coffee?
choices: A method of serving coffee in specialized cups
A standardized method of evaluating coffee flavor
A technique for growing coffee plants
A way of packaging roasted coffee
questions.answer: A standardized method of evaluating coffee flavor

questions.question: What is the first step in the cupping process?
choices: Tasting the brewed coffee
Breaking the crust
Evaluating the dry fragrance of ground coffee
Adding hot water to the grounds
questions.answer: Evaluating the dry fragrance of ground coffee

questions.question: Why do cuppers often slurp coffee loudly during tasting?
choices: To cool the coffee
To aerate the liquid and spread it across their palate
To impress other cuppers
To remove any remaining grounds
questions.answer: To aerate the liquid and spread it across their palate

questions.question: What does 'acidity' refer to in coffee tasting?
choices: The pH level of the coffee
The sour taste of over-extracted coffee
The bright, tangy quality of coffee
The amount of acid-forming bacteria in the beans
questions.answer: The bright, tangy quality of coffee

questions.question: What tool do coffee professionals often use to describe flavors with precision?
choices: The SCA Flavor Wheel
A pH meter
A refractometer
A coffee glossary
questions.answer: The SCA Flavor Wheel

questions.question: What is the 'body' of coffee referring to?
choices: The shape of the coffee bean
The weight or thickness of the coffee in the mouth
The caffeine content
The overall flavor profile
questions.answer: The weight or thickness of the coffee in the mouth

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT typically evaluated during coffee cupping?
choices: Aroma
Acidity
Caffeine content
Aftertaste
questions.answer: Caffeine content

questions.question: What is the purpose of 'breaking the crust' during cupping?
choices: To mix the coffee grounds
To cool the coffee faster
To release and evaluate aromas
To start the extraction process
questions.answer: To release and evaluate aromas

questions.question: How can improving quality control practices benefit coffee-producing countries like Timor-Leste?
choices: By increasing coffee consumption locally
By reducing the need for farm labor
By leading to higher prices for their coffee
By eliminating the need for certifications
questions.answer: By leading to higher prices for their coffee

questions.question: What is a potential consequence of poor green coffee grading?
choices: Faster roasting times
Increased caffeine content
Inconsistent roasting and poor cup quality
Higher market prices
questions.answer: Inconsistent roasting and poor cup quality

questions.question: Which organization typically sets standards for coffee cupping protocols?
choices: World Coffee Research
International Coffee Organization
Specialty Coffee Association (SCA)
Fairtrade International
questions.answer: Specialty Coffee Association (SCA)

questions.question: What is the primary difference between primary and secondary defects in green coffee?
choices: Primary defects are visible, secondary are not
Primary defects significantly impact quality, secondary have lesser impact
Primary defects occur before processing, secondary after
Primary defects affect flavor, secondary affect aroma
questions.answer: Primary defects significantly impact quality, secondary have lesser impact

questions.question: What role does the roast profile play in coffee quality?
choices: It determines the caffeine content
It affects the bean size
It plays a crucial role in determining the final flavor
It influences the bean's moisture content
questions.answer: It plays a crucial role in determining the final flavor

questions.question: Why is uniform bean size important in coffee roasting?
choices: It makes the coffee more visually appealing
It ensures even heat distribution and consistent roasting
It increases the coffee's market value
It improves the coffee's aroma
questions.answer: It ensures even heat distribution and consistent roasting

questions.question: What is direct trade in the context of coffee sourcing?
choices: Selling coffee directly to consumers
Trading coffee futures on the stock market
Roasters buying directly from growers, often at higher prices
Exchanging different coffee varieties between farms
questions.answer: Roasters buying directly from growers, often at higher prices

questions.question: What distinguishes specialty coffee from commodity coffee?
choices: Specialty coffee is always organic
Commodity coffee is always cheaper
Specialty coffee focuses on high-quality, often single-origin coffees
Commodity coffee is always sold in whole bean form
questions.answer: Specialty coffee focuses on high-quality, often single-origin coffees

questions.question: What is the main purpose of a coffee cooperative?
choices: To increase coffee consumption
To set global coffee prices
To provide mutual benefits for member farmers
To regulate coffee imports and exports
questions.answer: To provide mutual benefits for member farmers

questions.question: What does Fair Trade certification aim to ensure?
choices: The fastest shipping of coffee
The highest quality coffee
Better prices and working conditions for farmers
The most expensive coffee on the market
questions.answer: Better prices and working conditions for farmers

questions.question: What is a key requirement for Organic coffee certification?
choices: Coffee must be shade-grown
Coffee must be grown without synthetic pesticides or fertilizers
Coffee must be hand-picked
Coffee must be wet-processed
questions.answer: Coffee must be grown without synthetic pesticides or fertilizers

questions.question: What is a value chain in the context of coffee production?
choices: The nutritional value of different coffee varieties
The full range of activities required to bring coffee from production to consumer
The chain of custody for fair trade certification
The process of valuing coffee farms for sale
questions.answer: The full range of activities required to bring coffee from production to consumer

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT typically a stage in the coffee value chain?
choices: Production
Roasting
Genetic modification
Retail
questions.answer: Genetic modification

questions.question: What is the primary challenge of transitioning to organic coffee production?
choices: Increased pest problems
Higher labor costs
Reduced yield during the transition period
Difficulty finding buyers
questions.answer: Reduced yield during the transition period

questions.question: How does cupping contribute to quality control in coffee production?
choices: It determines the caffeine content of beans
It helps identify defects and assess overall quality
It speeds up the roasting process
It increases the market value of all evaluated coffees
questions.answer: It helps identify defects and assess overall quality

questions.question: What is the significance of 'single-origin' in specialty coffee?
choices: It means the coffee is from a single plant
It indicates coffee from one specific geographic location or farm
It refers to coffee that's only sold in one country
It means the coffee was processed using a single method
questions.answer: It indicates coffee from one specific geographic location or farm

questions.question: Why is selective harvesting important for coffee quality?
choices: It reduces the need for pesticides
It ensures only ripe cherries are picked, improving overall quality
It makes the harvesting process faster
It increases the yield of coffee plants
questions.answer: It ensures only ripe cherries are picked, improving overall quality
